reviewText:
This isn't your average wargame. It's not World of Tanks. It's not Panzer General.

This is massive. It's a simulation of the largest ground conflict in history. It models weather, ammunition, supply, logistics, partisans, air warfare, and of course combat. But because it's massive it can be daunting.

With all of that details come the challenge. At times it can be difficult to know if you're making the right choice. The interface can, at times, be overwhelming. All of the sudden a unit is highlighted in red. Why? It's not always evident immediately what is happening, or if it's significant. (Red highlight means it's out of supply range)\n
I'd recomend starting with the 3 turn Scenario Road to Minsk. It's a quick fix, shows you the basics, but also is complex enough to offer a lot of replayability. With some of the longer scenarios it's easy to get lost and just see a wave of units. With the Minsk scenario you have a difficult objective. Not because the battles are hard, but because you must grab massive quantities of territory on top of conquering the enemy. For an added challenge, try the Soviet side. The game tacticvs change completely.

Which brings me to the full campaign. The monster that is Barbarossa. For myself it's too big. It's a massive theatre of war that quite frankly is daunting. Check out Grey Hunters Let's Play for a truly epic story.

I'd love to see more scenarious I can tackle in an evening. I'd love to see tooltips to tell me exactly why that unit is highlighted yellow. Or why that attack failed.

Through all of the detail and interface is an entertaining game. The first time you play just click and go. Then learn to encircle, learn to use multiple hexes (hint, select one hex to attack, then hover your mouse over the neighbors), then start longer games.

War in the East is difficult, no doubt about it, but it's also an entertaining simulation.
voteText: 104 of 120 people (87%) found this review helpful 4 people found this review funny

reviewText:
Purchased WitE back in the day, which makes me old as 2010 isn't really Back in the Day. BitD is actually 1973 with the release of a paper hex map / cardboard counter game by the name of Drang Nach Osten. The map was about 4' x 5', the counters totaled over 1,500 individual pieces. Add the expansion Unentschieden! (yes, they invented what would become DLC BitD), and the maps got bigger, with thousands more counters. It took hours just to set up, before ever actually playing. And the play... we met every Saturday night for about a year, and only got into 1943 before marriage, college, the military and various nervous disorders most often resemblng German and Russian language Tourette Syndrome broke up the group and brought the endevour to an end.

All of which is only backstory to my purchase of War in the East - technology has granted us the ability to actually play the beast that is The Great Patriotic War at the operational level without renting a hall and losing our minds. It's been done a number of times in recent decades, but Gary Grigsby has done it the best, by a wide margin. If you've read this far and have any idea what I'm talking about. AND are interested in the subject, then buy this game. I'd forgotten how good it is (getting it on Steam has reintroduced me and taken me away from other CCG and FPS for the past weeks), and how easy it is to immerse oneself in it. But back in the saddle it's the only thing I'll be doing for a while.

Like: It's the @#$%&*! East Front done right, for Zhukov's sake!

Dislike: It's 01:43 after a full work day, again, and I'm too tired to keep playing.

reviewText:
I would pay $300.00 for this game if I could just get all of the time I wasted trying to get other WWII Barbarossa games to do what this game does so effortlessly, i.e. Unity of Command is a fun game but because it is smaller scale even in the map editor UoC couldn't deliver my craving for a balls deep plunge into wide open Russia during Barbarossa 41.  This game rewards the knowledge you gain from each turn, and you start feeling like those Kraut armies of yours are all your own well disciplined children that are ready to wreak sytematic havoc and destruction on the Russians ahead.  You will feel proud of them as they attack fearlessly, with you knowing Hitler's meddling won't do them in this time.  You are going to show the world what a well organized modern army can do to it's enemies.  (at least this is how I felt after getting comfortable with my personal Russian whoop-♥♥♥ mechanism).

Forget Road to Minks, just start with the 224 turn 41-45 Barbarossa map and start going balls deep into Russia.
You will be thinking what a bunch of German generals thought in the first few weeks, Moscow by Labor Day perhaps.
Little by little your respect grows for the enormity of this map, the challenges of supply, an enemy driven by the whims of a brutal dictator, and the wonders of finding yourself balls deep in a vast and mysterious Soviet landscape.  Just start over each time you learn something awesome so by the 3rd or 4th Barbarossa you are feeling much more confident with your boys because you have the needed trigger time" from 20 or so hours of gameplay.  I like a game where I can say
recommended: hit me with your best shot
hoursPlayed: let's see what you got!" and still have fun if you fail to get an objective you set for yourself.  After 70ish hours of gameplay

reviewText:
I'll start by saying this game is certainly not for everyone. The price should be enough to scare away anyone from making an impulse purchase they will regret. That said, if you are looking for an incredibly detailed depiction of the Eastern Front in WW2, look no further.

If you don't want to tackle the whole enchilada, you can have plenty of fun playing the smaller scenarios depicting the individual Army Groups during Barbarossa, or other scenarios covering events later in the war. This is where I've spent all of my time and I have enjoyed it. One day I will take on the full campaign, but not yet.

My biggest personal surprise when I started playing the game was just how easy it is to pick up the basic controls. Moving units, attacking, seeing what's what, it's all very intuitive after playing through just the tutorial. Of course, there's a ton more to the game than that, but it's great that you can hop right in and get to the action.

I wouldn't jump in blindly, given the price tag, but if you are interested in the setting or just a lover of strategy, you can't go wrong with GG's War in the East.

Note: I played the game a lot before it was available on Steam, which my play time here doesn't reflect.

reviewText:
Kenchis AKA Cannonfodder

The Good

* IGOUGO and weekly turns make the game manageble and playable for wargamers that are time constrained (personally, I play War in the Pacific: Admirals Edition a lot, a monster with the one day is one turn structure...)
* Not for the faint of heart. It should actually have this printed on the box....
* Very. very detailed OOB and leader database
* Modable to a high degree
* Fun and challenging AI that can be tuned to your level of competence (by giving it bonuses)
* It is the 26th of June
date: 1941.. Your infantry smashed through the front line and Panzer Gruppe 2 and 3 just linked up west of Minsk. Infantry are already working on reducing the large pocket formed. Your tanks have fuel but the supply lines are long and the infantry is behind... What do you do
recommended:
where do you go? YOU are in command...."

The Bad

* The air game is under developed and can be "gamed"
* IGOUGO and weekly turns can leave you wondering "what the hell just happened" in PBEM...
* Supply system is fairly basic and although it does constrain you it does not constrain you enough...
* The combat engine is very detailed and fun to dig in but it does complicate the game. Even the smallest tuning of devices can have large macro effects on the war
* Not for the faint of heart. It should actually have this printed on the box....

The future?

2by3 have used the base War in the East engine to develop War in the West (not available on steam). I've spent some hours in that game and while it introduces some features that are a bit rough around the edges (amphibous invasion
voteText: Eastern front box) it shows great promise in other areas (improvements to the supply system
helpfulPercent:
a new air engine).


Conclusion?

When you invest in War in the East
votesHelpful: you invest in a good time now but also in the future of a game engine that grognards aka war gaming enthusiasts will enjoy for years to come!"

reviewText:
Gary Grigsby's War in the East embraces the whole campaign on the Eastern Front, including the Balkans, and Central Europe. That's a period from 1941 to 1945 with numerous scenarios covering a number of campaigns. The game's really a board game that has been changed into computer software, with all its benefits, such as no dice and counter hassle, no CRT hassle (combat results table), no problems with a huge map or simulating the fog of war, everything being automatically calculated, and so on and so forth.

The counters represent divisions. You can also use battalions, regiments, and brigades, but smaller units are treated in a more abstract way. Each unit has a meticulously researched historical organisation and equipment. The game is played on a huge map consisting of 36,000 hexes. It simulates air war, logistics, weather, as well as amphibious and airborne landings. You can play against the AI or against a human opponent. Each turn represents a week.

The developer continuously supports this product. There have been numerous patches so far, fixing bugs, balancing gameplay, and generally improving the simulation.

With regard to complaints over the price of this gem, let's take a look at these board games by GMT ( http://www.gmtgames.com/c-16-east-front-series.aspx ):

1. Barbarossa: Army Group Center, 1941 (mind you - only a small fraction of the Eastern Front) = $65
2. Barbarossa: Army Group North, 1941 (again, only a small fraction of the Eastern Front) = $102
3. Barbarossa: Army Group South, 1941 (again, only a small fraction of the Eastern Front) = $89
4. Barbarossa: Crimea (a tiny fraction of the Eastern Front) = $79
5. Barbarossa: Kiev to Rostov (again, only a small fraction of the Eastern Front) = $85
6. Typhoon! (again, only a small fraction of the Eastern Front) = $75

TOTAL: that's $65+$102+$89+$79+$85+$75=$495 (that's roughly €443 or £318) - and it still doesn't cover all the campaigns that Gary Grigsby's War in the East offers...

Another good case in point is Total War by HMS/GRD ( http://hmsgrd.com/wordpress/?page_id=16 ): take a look at the price of Total War. That's $234. It's a remake of Fire in the East, and it only covers the period from... the summer of 1941 to the spring of 1942... - a lot less than Gary Grigsby's War in the East...

To conclude, taking the above into account, the price, whether it's €51, €73, or €83 (including both add-ons), is really a bargain. Gary Grigsby's War in the East offers a lot more than all the above games taken together and it serves it in a computerised, automated, and a lot more comfortable and convenient form, for a much lower price. Of course, you need to like playing wargames to appreciate this.

If you're into realistic wargames and WWII simulations, I really recommend this product to you.

reviewText: With the amount of hours I have in this game it is hard to find time to write a review.  Believe me that all the hours have been well spent on an awesome game with my current hours spent over 2,000.  Please note that I had this game before being available on Steam and have countless hours played before switching to a steam account to run the game.\n\nHaving said the above what I can say about this game is that the developers are still hard at work improving the game based on feedback from the community on their forums.  That in and of itself is a huge plus!!!  Playing either side gives you the feel that you are actually there commanding the units that actually took part in War in the East.  This game takes dedication and the ability to learn from your mistakes.  Above all this game truly shines in Player vs Player really testing you against a real opponent.  This game isn't for the feint of heart & will challenge you at every turn versus other players.  If you are looking for easy mode this game isn't for you.  If you love a challenge and see how well you place against others then I highly recommend this game.

reviewText:
I'm not going to to beat around the bush -- War in the East (WitE) is simply the best turn-based operational-scale strategy game I've ever played. My Steam playtime is a drop in the bucket; I've been playing the DRM-free version regulalrly for a couple of years.

It has both a huge scope, with tons of crunchy details, and a really well-constructed GUI that makes all this scope very managable. The AI is decent on defense, though if you want to play as the Soviets or the late-war Germans you'll need to find a PBEM opponent.

This is NOT a game for begining wargamers. For that you'll want Unity of Command or Panzer Corps (both also on Steam). But for veterans of historical strategy, this game can't be beat.

reviewText:
This is THE WW2 Eastern Front strategy game.
My number of hours played is not showing all those hours spent before the game got on steam, so disregard that number. I have played this game alot, and it is a great game.
You need to manage alot of aspects, such as;
-supply lines
-generals (which one goes where)
-how to utilize your airforce
-when to attack and when to defend
-where to push
-which army/army group to place those support units you have
-and tons more

That is only against the AI, this game really shines when you play it as pbem, since playing against another player is always something completely different than playing against the AI.

If you want a game you will master from the start, this is not it. If you want a game that challenges you, and will give you 100s of hours of fun, then this IS it.

reviewText:
I have  been into strategy games for some time - back since the days of civ 1. This is one of the best war games  I have come across. I haven't played 65 hours yet. Left the machine on and it's counted it. More like 20 hours so far.

So on to the review.

Positives

epic war on a large scale
large amount of detail
customisable
enjoyment improves as you learn
difficult/realistic as axis player v computer on normal - although did manage a major victory in the road to Lennigrad on first normal play.

Negatives

non intuative game interface. Actually had to read the manual tseveral times to even grasp the basics. I still get frustrated that I can't just click on something and it takes me there - it really doesn't. This nearly spolit my enjoyment of the game. For example Hearts of Iron 2 game interface is miles better. Playing as soviet v computer - to easy on normal already. Despite massive losses you can withdraw to fortify and defend. Even without knowing the supply system it was fairly simple.

Multiplayer

Hadn't tried this so far. Tried registering earlier which failed.

Verdict

Despite the interface flaws this is a fantastic game if you can buy it on sale. Steep learning curve even for us strategy/war game specialists.
voteText: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
You won't find a more detailed division level east front game on steam. Be advised this is a monster wargame.

1941-45 @ one week per turn. Old school...I do my turn and then you do yours. Rinse and repeat until victory or (player) morale failure.

Division and Bde level (bns & rgts assigned at Corps/Army level, CoC modelled very well

Units tracked by various types of supply (fuel, ammo...) fatigue, experience, morale...oh and by squad, mg and tank

The course of the war is one of amazing highs and lows regardless of the side you choose. Risks will have to be taken and disasters WILL occur. It will flow historically more or less if losses are near historical levels and skill levels aren't too far off but more or less casualties can lead to a very different army than seen historically. For example...woe to the Russian who threw away too many lives in low odds attacks and careless encirclements in 1942. Instead of standing up to the nazi invaders toe to toe...the retreat may very well continue throughout 43. I have won the game as the Germans in 1944 (admittedly against the ai)...panzers still pushing with all that late war goodness. Also been stopped cold in 42.

The war in the east from 1941-45 was by far the most brutal and total war ever fought by mankind. If you are seriously interested in learning about this conflict (and for anyone interested in military history, all other conflicts pale in comparison) this game is the only choice to make. Your only other serious options are TOAW, dosbox with this game's predecessor and vassal with a good boardgame. For the grogs and children of the grogs I can't possibly recommend this game enough. Don't give the price a second thought. 2 years after you delve into this game do the math...dollars vs hours. It will be cheap at that point. The thing is you're not done. Do the math again after four years and then six. Yeah, it's one of those games.

For the impatient, for those not interested at looking at the Soviet-German war (yeah and Hungry, Romania, Slovakia, Finland, Croatia and even a division from neutral Spain!) in it's totality, for those demanding something looking and sounding 'awesome' or immediate gratification move along. This isn't for you.

Do not be concerned at the age of this beast. Like a fine bottle of Scotch it has only improved with age. It is now very near a state of balance where any further changes carry both diminishing returns and the risks of unintended consequences. The game is ready for you.

reviewText:
I like the game very much.  There is a lot of strategy and difficulty plus a steep learning curve but that's okay.  I managed a decisive victory in the tutorial (small map you still have to figure out how to do stuff) but was unable to do better than allow a soviet minor victory on Road to Minsk (tried it twice I think this scenario needs one more turn-at top speed my units couldn't get to the edge even though we slaughtered hordes of Russians.  205k to my 11k.  I think even if I didn't win I learned a lot and had fun.  That's why we buy these things I guess :)

It is very detailed, there is a 400 page manual and if you want complexity and realism it is here.  If you don't like thinking much then it's not your type of game though.

reviewText:
This game rocks.  I heard this is a very complicated game but I am shock how easy to get into it even without reading the manual.  Just right click to move and right click again to attack.  Of course eventually you will need to read the manual for better understanding regarding to rules like supply, production etc.  But this is far easiler to learn than I first believe.

If I have to pick some issues from this game.  I will say this game does not have enough tool tips.  There are too many symbols or short form that is not shown in the game unless reading the manual and remember what they mean.  There is no in game tutorial to show you things step by step.  I really would like it to copy the civilization manual system that the whole manual is integrated inside the game,    The rule book is pretty dry and it shows you tons of mathematical formulas and functions.  I will say it is essential if you are a competitor.  But it makes reading the manual very hard like reading a school book.  I will suggest just make the manaul without the formual but only the logic of different topics, and add the formulas and functions in the appendix section.  Afterall, this is war and in really we will never know how much more difficult to move through EZOC.

It looks like I critcize a lot about this game.  But in fact I am not.  I love this game.  I can easily give it a solid 9/10.  If it integrades the manual into the game and show more tips when I move the cursor to different symbol  I will give it a 10.  Very good wargame.  Maybe even the best one.

reviewText:
Gary Grigsby's War in the East simulates warfare on the Easter Front in the Second World War. It is a game you will either spend tens (ok, hundreds) of hours with... or you will just not get over the first hurdle of user interface & the manual. If you get over the interface and the hefty manual (highly recommended for new players, 100's of pages of important stuff), you need to gain understanding a rather delicate web of interdependencies, between morale, supply, air raids, HQ, generals, encirclements and evacuation. Than, AI will be piece of cake - but it will take tens and tens of hours to get to stage when you need to start playing Soviet Union on Hard to get some challenge.

However, the game begins when you start playing against humans. And you will find out that you have much to learn and that you do not know how to play. You will find that there are tricks, fine tricks and almost exploits. In any case, the game against expert player is quite different than even against very tough AI. Things are unfair, no matter which side you play... but also fun. You will understand that the system of interdependencies is much deeper and that micromanagement is much more important. I guarantee that during games against humans you will reach total despair, no matter which side you play.

Hint: choose Soviets for your first game against human - they can fight even after you made quite some mistakes. Germans, Germans require a player class or two better than the opponent to succeed. But expertly played Axis is a very challenging opponent, even for an expert Soviet. At least until you stabilize in '42-'43.

To sum up, the game if you choose to get deep into it, will take hundreds of hours of play.  Worth it? Worth it if moving symbols over hexes is your thing. However, be careful if your family situation is strained and you should not get into a very complex game which will take hundreds of hours of your life. And if you do not like complex games, that is not the game for you.


Pros:
Complexity
Details
Most complete warfare simulation of the Eastern Front
Really well thought out - though one can appreciate the finer design only after hundreds of hours played
Cons:
Complexity - not a game for everyone
Predicting the results of battles can be frustrating and require a lot of skill (one needs to take into account all the variables, that is morale, supply, type of units fighting, arms in the units etc - the numbers on the counters are only rough guidelines). That is doubly frustrating against expert human players as they can improve supply, morale etc. by skilled play leading to more difficult prediction of the results - as you do not know everything due to fog of war.
Some balancing issues when facing expert humans
Simulation of warfare only; no option to simulate production, interfere with the units armaments, etc
Your social life will be in danger if you like complex wargames
Check the AAR's here:  AAR Forum [www.matrixgames.com]
My opponent AAR (two year old) - myself playing Germans	[www.matrixgames.com]

reviewText: Gary Grigsby for those not familiar with computer wargames, is pretty much the undisputed king of complex grand tactical and strategy WW2 wargames. This game is worth even buying as the boxed version with its weight manual - get this and the add ons - heaps of scenarios and all of them a great challenge. Just the 3 turn Road to Minsk scenario will demand a few playthroughs to figure out how to win for either side.\nThe game has alot of complexity but also atmosphere in spades with its intro movie and in game music and sounds.

reviewText:
I've played a lot of this game before it switched to steam.  This is a very deep and engaging wargame.  There may seem like a lot of moving parts, but fun in SP can be had just by moving counters and making sure your number is 2 times their number for attacks.  There are some great let's plays and videos out there if you really want to dive into the meat of one of the deepest and most engrossing wargames ever made.

The only thing on my wishlist would be fewer support units.

9/10 get this game if you like counters and pixeldudes.
voteText: 10 of 21 people (48%) found this review helpful

reviewText: A very good strategy simulation. Despite the apparent complexity of a thick rule book and detailed database it is essentially a simple game to pick up and play for anyone used to hex based wargaming; at its simplest left click on a unit, right click where you want it to go, right click to attack. The smaller scenarios can be fished in a few hours or less; many scenarios are quite easy to win in the easiest settings - but you can adjust things to force a more historical outcome.. The campaign may take a few hours a turn in some cases and the AI is good, but slow.
